My parents and I were starving and ate all our banchan because we thought we would never get our dishes.Came on a Tuesday, and it took 2 hours to eat lunch. Unacceptable. Food was whack. I'm from DC, where Korean BBQ from Northern Virginia makes you cry. Who puts romaine lettuce/red cabbage in bibimbap? Burning their dolsot bibimbap (I like the rice at the bottom toasty and crispy...not completely charred black!)? Their dumplings don't look handmade. And their barley tea barely tasted like toasted barley. Only good thing was that their portions were relative large -- their man duk soup came in a huge mixing bowl.But this place is just so wrong. And they allowed a group of 8 people to pay by credit card separately. Which took checkout so much longer. Fix it or close up shop.

reviews.name: Travis A.
reviews.review: Best Korean food in Nashville.  I get take out from here literally every other week.  Some of my faves:Mool Mandu - steam dumpling appetizerBul Go Gi - Chicken or BeefBi Bim Bob - rice, meat and vegetables served in a hot stone pot (best eating in)Duk Man Doo Guk - dumpling soup w/ rice cakesTheir banchan are good, but their kimchi is AMAZING.  I wish they would sell their own.  I would buy it by the big jar.Only negative I can think of is that they like to charge for extra steamed rice or banchan.  Service is a little "slow" when eating in, but that's to be a little expected.  This isn't O'Charleys... get over it.

reviews.name: David G.
reviews.review: Journeyed here for a group function during lunch.  I generally enjoy Korean food, but I have only had the food that my Korean friend and his family make.  I've never been to a Korean restaurant before.  Thus, maybe my review is skewed or not a proper baseline.That said, the service was not terribly good as has been mentioned in numerous reviews.  And, I'm sorry, but I'm not going to forgive someone for having horrible service just because "Asian places having service that sucks" as an over-generalization.  The service was terrible, absolutely terrible.The kimchi tasted just like my friend's mother makes it... freaking good.  The steamed and the fried dumplings (we ordered both at $6.95 each) were pretty good.  I ate from the steamed side mostly, but that's just because I tend to avoid fried foods for health purposes...  yeah, I'm weird.  Deal with it. :)The BBQ on your table was interesting.  I thought that it was neat that the smoked wood was actually at our table and the food was cooked there.  I disliked the fact that you had to order two meats to have BBQ at your table, though.  What if you came in as a single and wanted to have the experience?  Seems kinda crummy that you'd have to order more food than you'd eat in a sitting just because that's their requirement.  I don't see how the profit margins could be such that I'd be required to order two meats when the cheapest one is $16.95.  I'm sorry, but a half pound of chicken + labor + overhead doesn't cost you $16.95.  I should be able to order one.Pricing aside, the BBQ sirloin, BBQ chicken, and BBQ short ribs were all decent but not crispy due to uneven heat from the coals.  Moreover, the server definitely wanted us to eat less-than-completely cooked chicken.  I suggest you be the judge not your server.  Anyhow, I'd rather take trips deep into Antioch for something better.Overall, if you don't live in Antioch or Nolensville, then I don't really see a reason to journey out to Seoul Garden.  I've heard there is a better Korean place on Charlotte Avenue downtown - but I don't know its name (one of the other people at my table was talking about it).

reviews.name: Will M.
reviews.review: At least 7 of the best Korean dishes in Nashville reside here.  Basically each korean restaurant does a dish better than others.  So, you really have to know what to order.  That's true at many restaurants.   Larger asian populations have better asian restaurants.  3 star else where

reviews.name: Sarah G.
reviews.review: After living in LA for 17 years - I would say that I am obsessive about Korean BBQ. I was really surprised at the authenticity of the dishes and the depth of the menu at Seoul Garden.I could have closed my eyes and been in a Korean join in K-town LA. Easy.The hot coals for grilling is cool looking, but it does not really give you the constant heat you want for the meat to get nice and crispy on the outside.I would recommend ordering one meat dish at a time and NOT letting the server cook for you. They rush you. Put the meat on yourself and take your time, that is the beauty of Korean BBQ.As for the food itself - I was REALLY impressed and my taste bus were very happy. We had the Short rib and the bulgogi. We also had a Pork Kimchee dish ($12.95 - the one without tofu) that was a major winner. I will order that one again.There are a couple of things that are staples in the Korean restaurants in LA that I didn't see. A crisp green salad, god dipping sauces and the opportunity to cook the garlic cloves in the sesame oil (the shape of the grill prohibits it).Overall I loved it and I will go back to dive deeper into the menu.

reviews.name: Chad R.
reviews.review: My girlfriend and I have been to Seoul Garden two weekends in a row because we love it so much.  It is located in a strip mall on Edmonson Pike near Nolensville Road.  The decor is very nice and they have large tv's the feature Korean pop star shows that are fun to watch.  The restaurant is very clean and the servers are very attentive to your needs and prompt with the food. One weekend, I had a seafood soup and my girlfriend had a fried pork dish.  In addition,  they give you plenty of sides that are a mix of vegetables and tofu.  We both thought the food was delicious and really enjoyed it.  The next weekend we went back and my girlfriend had a chicken dish while I had a beef dish.  Once again, the food was delicious and we swore that some time, when we go back there, we will had some Korean BBQ.  So, two weekends in a row at Seoul Garden and we loved our experience and the food both times.  We will be going back!

reviews.name: Tori W.
reviews.review: Very good Korean food! I was actually surprised. The decor is not so attractive, but the food absolutely makes up for it. I had #31 (can't remember the name) and it was better than the first time I had it in NJ! It was a little pricey, but I wouldn't hold it against them. It's large portions and delicious!

reviews.name: Phyllis N.
reviews.review: All I can say is Excellent. I had #52 a stir fried squid with onions greenpeppers red peppers cabbage and a red sauce. Along with all the Kimchee's and rice.  Oh my gosh was it good. The server was nice and the place is really clean.

reviews.name: Linda C.
reviews.review: Decent Korean BBQ for Nashville but horrible service.  I've been to this restaurant twice now, each time receiving less-than-friendly service.  To sit at the grill tables, you'll have to order a minimum of 2 meat items which is understandable.  Two orders of meat will feed about 2-3 guests.   A plate of Bulgogi and Kalbi will run about $20/plate while Samgyeopsal costs about $17/plate.   Anybody that has eaten Korean BBQ at a more Asian populated city will know that's a bit pricier than normal.  But since we're in Nashville with limited choices, this is decent.  Seoul Garden uses hot coals instead of gas grills, so the servers will rush you to eat medium cooked meat to prevent too many grill plate changes.  If you like the meat crispy and not chew a piece of undercooked Samgyeopsal, please be prepared to receive some "looks" from the servers.They serve about 6-8 Banchan dishes which the servers have turned their nose if you ask for refills.  Please note that you'll have to specifically ask for how many orders of rice, they won't serve one per guest, unless you ask.  Also, even if you order 5 orders of meat at the grill table, asking for a 3rd helping of lettuce will result in a charge.  Final note, a 17% gratuity charge is automatically tacked on if you sit at the grill tables.If you're dying for the grill experience, give Seoul Garden a try.  If you don't care for it much, there are a few local joints that will serve it to you ready to eat with a smile.

reviews.name: Clara N.
reviews.review: This is the best place for Korean food! The soups, dumplings, noodle dishes, and everything is great! I have never had a bad meal and the service is excellent. Thumbs up and 5 stars.

reviews.name: Soukie K.
reviews.review: Comparing Seoul Garden dishes to the other 2 Korean restaurants, I say this is the least of my favorite. Their price is a big higher and their portions are less than the others. But, Seoul Garden is the only one that offers barbeque, and this is the only reason we occasionally go there. The atmosphere is really nice and pleasant though, they even have karaoke, but not sure if they play American karaoke.

reviews.name: Leah W.
reviews.review: Fantastic food and great prices compared to some of the other Korean restaurants that have been in the area.  I went at lunchtime and the service was fantastic.  A note about the hours - during the week, they close from 2-5 everyday, and then reopen for dinner.

reviews.name: kristen p.
reviews.review: I was not impressed by Seoul Garden at all. Unless of course you enjoy playing sign language back and forth with your waitress because she speaks no English (which technically could be a good sign in a restaurant like this but was not.). This is especially not fun being a vegetarian and hoping that your hand signals do not betray you and your waitress bequeath you with a big bowl of meat. Luckily she interpreted well. However the food was not great. Not even the banchan was just okay.The weirdest part of the whole experience was that all of the non Korean customers were all grouped together in one corner (set apart with dividers) of the restaurant. The people sitting at the tables around us noticed it too.This is just a weird place with mediocre food and a less than helpful... although friendly...staff.

reviews.name: Ek V.
reviews.review: I love the food here. The lunch specials are very resonably priced.  I would probably get the pork bul gogi everyday if I could.  The waitress has changed a lot. Before they were not very nice but now I think they are great.

reviews.name: Rita C.
reviews.review: Honestly...LOVE this place.  Considering I have yet to find much decent Asian food in Nashville, this was a definite surprise.  Yummy bugulgi, galbi, banchan, etc.  Not to mention late night Karaoke!  A redeeming star in Nashville's severely lacking Asian food scene.

reviews.name: Tramychiquita N.
reviews.review: Just a head up, I am Asian so would it give my review for an Asian restaurant any more credit? Actually my boss recommends me this place. I trust his recommendation since his ex girlfriend was Korean. So I took an hour drive from Kentucky to eat at Seoul Garden.Once I got inside the restaurant, I was like " am I in Korea ?".  The place literally reminds me of the Korean dramas I've watched, especially the Korean couples and groups eating and chatting in Korean. The restaurant is very clean, unlike the typical sappy Asian restaurants (minus the over-priced Japanese ones).I rarely saw grilled fish in Korean restaurants, even in bigger cities, but they have grilled fish in the menu here. I am absolutely love, love, love it. I do not know what type of fish it is; though, it has a crunchy, smoky taste and has lots of eggs inside.The small size dishes of kimchie and others, how I should say it?mmm look so cute haha ^ ^ The complimentary cold cinnamon tea is refreshing, it is good to wash off  the spicy taste.The price of my two grilled fishes, size dishes and tea is about $12, not bad at all.Best Korean joint in Nashville for sure!

reviews.name: Peter M.
reviews.review: This is solid, homey Korean food.  The grilled chicken was delicately cooked--super juicy and tender.  The kim chi sides were ok.  Flavors all around were warm and nicely balanced.  Just not as great as other Korean restaurants I've been to --especially Manna on Charlotte Ave, my favorite Korean restaurant anywhere (and in Nashville, how about that!)  I think my favorite part about this meal was it reminded me that it has been too long since I've been to Manna.

reviews.name: Eric B.
reviews.review: my introduction to korean food. the other review does make me want to go to hai woon dai. great place, and comes well recommended from me!eric b

reviews.name: Robert K.
reviews.review: Prior to Seoul Garden Restaurant, to my knowledge, I had never had Korean food before.  Korean food in general is pretty weird and I had not heard of most of the stuff that they had on the menu, so I stuck with what I knew!  I had the barbeque chicken, which was really good and they do a great presentation by preparing it at your table.  It was good, the side was some sort of seaweed thing and some Korean style veggies.  Try this place if you are in for something different, but you might want to research Korean food first!

reviews.name: Lauren F.
reviews.review: Wonderful service from the sweet and accommodating hostess.... the banchan were brought out a little too close to the serving of our meal but were delightful, kimchee, red chili tofu, bean sprouts, steamed broccoli. i love little bites. i got the bibimbop with meat in a hot bowl - highly recommended as it was cooking the whole time i was eating it, and by the time i dug down to the bottom some of the rice was crispy and crunchy which was an interesting contrast to the fried egg, cooked beef, and veggies. very fun dining experience. the grilled pork was also very flavorful but less exciting, served with rice but not veggies. the banchan were a good accompaniment though. definitely will go back.

reviews.name: Ben H.
reviews.review: This is a medium sized restaurant with fairly authentic Korean food.  The staff is a little slow sometimes.  The food on the other hand is very good and properly prepared.

reviews.name: Emily Y.
reviews.review: Brand New Korean restaurant in Nashville.  We actually went on Grand opening day. Service is spotty; food is ok.. This place is spotless clean though. Other Korean places in Nashville are so much better.  See Korea House or Hai Woon Dai.

reviews.name: Mike K.
reviews.review: Also known as Metro Cafe, this place offers great home style cooking at a great price.  Neat and clean atmosphere.  It is a favorite of those who know about this hidden gem attached to a retirement home.

reviews.name: Adam M.
reviews.review: Let me try to make a slightly more helpful review...It's hard to convince co-workers to go to what someone will inevitably call a "nursing home" for lunch -- and I'm happy that I now have the necessary information to confidently sell this place when I'm feeling some good food.More than a meat-and-three, this place was for me a little bit more like going to Whole Foods for lunch, which I love to do.  There was a cold deli case with a selection of about 10 cold salads (fresh fruit, waldorf, tortellini with broccoli and cauliflower, potato, maybe a three-bean salad, two kinds of chicken salad -- curry and "regular" [see important note about that below -- and maybe another one or two that I'm forgetting.Then there was a selection of four or five hot entrees.  Today's were meatloaf, teriyaki chicken and rice, salmon croquettes, shepherd's pie, and chicken tetrazzini -- along with 2 or 3 hot vegetables/sides.The pricing was set up something like this:  meat and two for $5.50, meat and three for $6.50, cold salad sampler (choice of three) for $4.50 or $5.00.  All of those "combos" included cornbread or roll and drink (fruit tea was maybe $0.50 extra).  You could also purchase individual items very reasonably...I want to say $1.50 for a cold side, $2.50 for a hot side, and $3.50 for an entree.  Something close to that.My shepherd's pie was very good.  The only thing that would have made it a little better, for me, was something gravy-like to hold the meat together.  As it was, it was more "loose-meat" style on the bottom, but was well-seasoned.  The amount of meat was generous...there were onions in the mix and other than that only a few small pieces of potato that I remember.  It was topped, of course, with mashed potatoes and the top was nicely and evenly browned with a garnish of a single bias-cut scallion sliver on top.  The macaroni and cheese was OK.  A little loose and oily for my taste, but still good.  (I would prefer it that way to the soupy, really rich style.)  The broccoli, cauliflower, and tortellini salad I had was maybe day-old but still tasted good.One of my friends enjoyed the chicken tetrazzini, green beans, and corn I believe.  All of it looked very good.My other friend enjoyed the fresh fruit but couldn't say the same for the chicken salad.  After tasting it, I had to agree with her.  It looked great -- much like my mom made -- fine ground and on the drier side with celery and maybe a nut or two.  What I wasn't able to tell until I tasted it though, was the addition of bleu cheese!  I admit that I'm not a fan of the moldy stuff, but even so...it just didn't feel right to me at all.  AT THE VERY LEAST, this type of a "polarizing" ingredient that is not really visibly apparent should be called out on the menu -- no excuses.  I told her to take it back, but she was too "nice".  I have no doubt that it was fresh and well-prepared; if you're a huge bleu cheese fan you probably would love it.  But again, if you're going to monkeying around with something like chicken salad, please make sure that you clue everyone in!There were a few dessert selections in the case...a huge cheesecake brownie and something else -- carrot cake, I believe.  At the cash register were HUGE cookies that sounded great, but had the consistency of a very dry and stale biscuit.  If I want something sweet next time I go (and it will probably be soon,) I'll try one of the fresh made desserts in the case.The employees (probably the owners, but I'm not sure) were very friendly.  Judging from the people I saw there and its "off-the-beaten-path" location, it seems like there were mostly regulars that like to go there for a quiet lunch and would like to keep it that way.  We arrived at about 11:20...everything was hot and fresh, it was nice and quiet, and there was plenty of seating.  (And no senior citizens to speak of, if anyone of your party is phobic of them for whatever strange reason.)  If I find out that the seniors at the adjoining retirement home are getting this food every day, I think I'm going to make an early bird reservation for 2047 or so.[Credit cards accepted; $4 minimum.]

reviews.name: Becky M.
reviews.review: Great service. Fresh food. Make it how you like it. A gyro with fries and drink cost me $6.54. That's a great lunch price.Near the Guitar Center.

reviews.name: A M.
reviews.review: The food was good (Not great) but the employees were more concerned on watching a TV show instead of taking care of their customers.  I'm all about customer service and these guys need a class or two about what the priorities are at a restaurant.

reviews.name: Craig J.
reviews.review: The Gyros are great!  The staff are AWESOME!  Would have given 5 stars but on my falafel combo the pita was chewy. They nuke it instead of grilling to warm it. Overall, nice and affordable lunch.

reviews.name: Ruiqiu K.
reviews.review: 2013/006I was about to head to the Thai/pan-Asian place around the corner for lunch, but my stomach saw this place first.I had the combo plate. When he asked if I wanted "cucumber or ranch", I thought he meant cucumbers, not the cucumber dressing. Had I known that, I wouldn't have asked for ranch.Anyway, the rice was salty, and the chicken was untouched. I did eat everything else on the plate, including the other protein, which I can't remember what it was. Must've been beef, as I remember wishing they offered lamb.The place was empty when I came in, but a line quickly formed as I was eating.

reviews.name: Shai R.
reviews.review: Good price for good food good quantity. Not a gourmet place, but the above is a match.

reviews.name: Timothy B.
reviews.review: Friendly staff. Great gyros! This is going on the list of places I frequent for lunch. The place is a bit small, but I went for the food, and I was not disapointed.

reviews.name: Marshall C.
reviews.review: So good in your mouth. Less than 7 dollars. Divey and delicious.

reviews.name: Stefanie P.
reviews.review: This place isn't that clean BUT... the food is fresh, the food is plentiful, and the price is right ($6.50 for a combo - big plate of food, drink, fries). Traffic can be a headache at lunchtime in that area but if you're craving fast greek food - check Kabab Gyro out!

reviews.name: Denver B.
reviews.review: Quick, good service and food always consistently good.  Aa far as quick Greek take out goes, it's tough to beat.

reviews.name: Daryl S.
reviews.review: I'm not impressed with Kabab Gyro.  The selection is mediocre and the place is a dump.  I didn't expect fine dining but it's actually unseemly there.  They gyro sandwich I ordered was not even among the average gyros I've eaten.  The french fries were removed from the fryer and dumped immediately onto my plate so there was too much oil.  Very loud old Arab movies playing on the tv doesn't add to the ambience, it just makes it weird.  I love gyro restaurants and enjoy middle eastern culture, but I won't go back to Kabab Gyro.

reviews.name: Courtney L.
reviews.review: Hands down the best and freshest sushi I've had in my area yet. Spicy is actually spicy. Tuna is actually tuna! Crab is.. well, actually crab!! And it's delicious. I also feel as if they offer some of the best selections I've seen. You're not overloaded like Sushime, but you have just enough options that while you may have favorites, you can easily pick something else completely different with no struggle. There's also other items on the menu for those who are not a fan of our sea friends!  It seems family owned and the staff are definitely attentive and warm, love em!

reviews.name: Maria S.
reviews.review: Trying to find a sushi place in Nashville has turned into a needle in a haystack.  The pros: service amazing, super friendly and attentive.  The ambiance great it's ideal for a date or a group.  They have sports on all tv's.  You can see your sushi being prepared.  Cons:  the sushi - left something to be desired.  Wasn't terrible but I wasn't amazed.  The oasis was my favorite roll.  I also had the No 9 and the crunchy crab.  The Kani salad - definitely not what I've been used to having nor was it good.  I'm trying it again but going for the hibachi next time.

reviews.name: Andrea B.
reviews.review: Great! So yummy and very close to my house! Aaaaand they carry my fave draft Hakutsuru. Yay BrAntioch

reviews.name: Cristi S.
reviews.review: So fresh & the quality can't be compared.    Highly recommend.   Our fav rolls include Osaka, tuna tango, and fireball!  Very reasonable in price and we have never been disappointed.

reviews.name: Elizabeth R.
reviews.review: Went on a Tuesday night and the sushi was AMAZING! The service was great. She didn't speak much English but she was so sweet and understood even when we wanted to order more after our first order lol

reviews.name: Christopher S.
reviews.review: The saki bombs were awesome. We got a very big spread of sushi and it was awesome. Great service.

reviews.name: Jonathan S.
reviews.review: I've been to so many sushi places I can't count.   The main reason being my wife loves sushi.   I would have to say this place is an average sushi place.  Not bad and not good.   I ordered salmon roe, ikura to most of us,  it was old and a very small portion.  It was probably good they gave me so little but I feel bad for the days to come when other people order it.  Also the service was rather slow in sushi terms.  Especially when we were two of the five people in the place.

reviews.name: Abby A.
reviews.review: My boyfriend and I have been craving sushi for sometime. We've drove past this place a ton of times and we decided to try it. We got the TNT roll, the SOS roll, and the spicy crab roll. DELICIOUS! It wasn't too terribly expensive either! This place was pretty chill, not too many people. We will definitely be back!

reviews.name: Mia F.
reviews.review: I am never disappointed in the sushi! Reasonable prices and fast service. Prompt polite service with dine in and quick turn around for take out. The floor is never really busy. . . but, the atmosphere is nice. The current sushi chef has worked at many great sushi houses in Nashville and now he is at this gem. I love Salmon heaven and my husband loves the Happy roll.

reviews.name: Justine F.
reviews.review: In the past, Sushi O Sushi has been one of my favorite sushi spots in the Nashville area. I am particularly fond of the TNT and Salmon Heaven roll. Very fresh and yummy.However, it pains me to say that the service has gone down hill. I recently dined here on a Friday night with 3 other people and it was slow. We waited about 10 minutes before a server came to get our drink order and then another 20 to take a food order. On top of that, we waited an unusual amount of time for  food to be delivered to the table and it wasn't very busy. There only seemed to be two servers on the floor and they constantly looked overwhelmed. It took an additional amount of time to get our checks, and the place was practically empty at that point. If the place had been slammed, I would have understood. Not once did we even get a "sorry about the wait". It was as though they were completely oblivious to the situation. Everyone in our group was annoyed with the lack of service and we aren't hard people to please. The last couple times I have eaten here, I've noticed a similar decline in speedy service, but this evening had to be the worst. I've always been a fan of Sushi O Sushi and again, I think they have great food. But if they don't step up their service, they may lose a lot of their regular customers.

reviews.name: Larisa N.
reviews.review: I was told the sushi are great here. Absolutely nothing special and not worth driving so fat for them. I won't be coming back. Well, at least it wasn't expensive.

reviews.name: Jayla B.
reviews.review: LOVE the sweet banana roll. This is our go to place they are so nice and always take good care of us.

reviews.name: Jenna D.
reviews.review: Took 45 min to get water, the food came out wrong. The food tasted ok, but wasn't anything memorable. Then the checks were also incorrect. Waiter wasn't too concerned with trying to fix anything. Too many good places in nashville to spend money here.

reviews.name: Jacob V.
reviews.review: We used to visit here at least once per week. The co-owner was typically our hostess and server. She got to the point where she knew what we would order before we were ready. As she began attending school or something, they started having other servers who were slow to take orders, slow to serve, and virtually ignored you until you were ready to leave.We finally decided to stop giving them any more business, until last week when no other sushi place was open when we were ready to eat. Same thing - slow getting attention, and I ordered exactly what I had every time before - sushi special with no octopus, squid, eel, or mackerel. About 10 minutes go by before the server came back to explain what "chef's choice" means on the sushi special. I finally just told her that I've ordered the exact same thing every time, and have never had a problem. She told me they couldn't do it, so I asked her to just cancel the order and we'd go somewhere else.  Eventually she came back and said they would do it "this time."Too expensive, for consistently terrible service, and mediocre quality anymore, especially when Sushime is directly across the street and is SO much better and better atmosphere. Sorry, Sushi O Sushi, that was my last time.

reviews.name: Alexandria R.
reviews.review: Very good restaurant. Their sushi is great! They are one of the few places that I like their Yummy roll. Their soy sauce is a little salty, but the wonderful sushi definitely makes up for it. Their hibachi dinners are great as well. They have the best house salad--the dressing is amazing. The staff is really friendly and care a lot about the customers, we eat here all the time.

reviews.name: Jess B.
reviews.review: Quality used to be a lot better. We ate here several times over a year..it began declining and was expensive to begin with. On our last two visits and final visit, we sat for 25 minutes without being waited on...and the server was sitting at a table 20 feet from us...We were finally served, no follow up and had to go to the bar for our check...the rolls were sloppy, ill cut, looked like week old fish. The bill was $75 for a small order. We never went back. I felt ripped off and after being a big tipper and repeat customer, felt cheated.  We have never been back after going back again giving them the "everyone has an off day". I am amazed they are still in business

reviews.name: Charnelle Y.
reviews.review: I love this place, enjoy the atmosphere and the sushi is always good... Favorite ginger dressing as well yummy!!!

reviews.name: Shirley F.
reviews.review: Really enjoyed my Regular Sushi platter. Got it to go so no reason contact. Will go back.

reviews.name: Leslie W.
reviews.review: It was hard for me to leave behind my old sushi restaurant hundreds of miles away, until I found this little gem. My boyfriend and I thought we would try it, being new to TN and everything around us. We practically ordered 12 different types of sushi, and inhaled all of it. It was so good, we go once a month and try a different roll every time. And each time we go the sushi is better and better. If you want sushi eat here for sure! If you're looking for classic Asian cuisine, like Lo mien or a box dinner, this is not your kind of place.

reviews.name: Stefanie M.
reviews.review: Because we had recently been to Sushime we had something to compare it to and we really liked Sushi O Sushi better.  The fish was equally as fresh, the rolls were actually rolled a little loose, but the service was wonderful.  We sat at the bar and the Chef was very interactive...he was friendly and made a few recommendations for us.This will end up being our go-to sushi place in our neighborhood.

reviews.name: Michelle P.
reviews.review: Sushi O Sushi is definitely one of my favourite places to eat in Nashville. I can't eat fish, but their chicken teriyaki dinner is one of the best I've ever had. Whenever I'm visiting Nashville, I go to this restaurant at least once - more if I can! The staff are super friendly, and the food is consistently great. Just be sure that you call ahead since the hours on their website aren't always accurate.

reviews.name: Carmen P.
reviews.review: oh, my heart aches to give these sweet people only two stars, but, my husband was ill after eating here, and i only ate like 2 pieces of my tnt roll (unheard of, normally i eat the whole rock city roll--similar--at fulins, in one bite). the miso soup was very salty, though the miso soup at sushime is incredible!we also had some banana topped roll (which at sushime was incredible, just not so much here).the service is just lovely, and super sweet though.we asked for a leftover box, but after my husband became ill, and i was just disappointed in my rolls, we threw the left overs away at home  :(  i never ever ever ever ever ever ever ever waste food--ever. it actually concerns my husband how willing i am to eat expired food and whatnot, but i was so disappointed in my rolls, that i didn't even want them. (first world problems, i know :( )

reviews.name: Aaron H.
reviews.review: Pretty decent. Went for lunch. Got a bento box meal. The beef left a bit to be desired.  The bowl the miso soup came in was covered in dried food particles.  The sushi was good.  Value was good

reviews.name: Toomie S.
reviews.review: "Can I get my beer with dinner?" Umm..apparently the answer is no, cause she didn't want to forget? Food was mediocre and the service horrendous. Underwhelming at best. Go to Sushime across the street instead.

reviews.name: Anne M.
reviews.review: Yummy! One of the best sushi places in Nashville. Zumi and Sushi O Sushi are my favorites. Not a fan of Pete's Sushi in Brentwood. My favorite roll is here is the Salmon Miso though there are so many good ones!

reviews.name: Cathy S.
reviews.review: What a great surprise to wander into Sushi O Sushi to discover Eichii, our very favorite Sushi Chef in all of Nashville!  If you love Ingiri, sit a spell at the Sushi bar and give Eichii a try!  He won't disappoint!  For the diner that prefers a table or a booth, Sushi O Sushi's menu offers a great choice of Japanese and Korean favorites and inventive choices of sushi rolls.  My husband loved the fresh grilled salmon and my plate of spicy noodles and chicken were delicious.  Cold Sapporo, nice wine choices, all from a bottle!  Located on Nolensville Road, at the corner of Brentwood and Nashville, we will get "jiggy" with Sushi O Sushi because everyone needs a taste of Japan a lot closer to home!

reviews.name: Tabitha S.
reviews.review: This place it great. It is never crowded when I go and the service is fast and friendly. For the first time I tried the fried sushi rolls and they were amazing. If I dont feel like driving all the way down town I will hit up this place. Very delish!

reviews.name: Sam W.
reviews.review: I love this restaurant and we go there at least 3 times per month. The menu is really overwhelming with lots of options but you will certainly find something that you like. I've seen comments that this place is expensive but I really wouldn't go to a cheap restaurant to have raw fish. We usually order sushis with raw fish and it always looks and tastes fresh, not the sticky fish that you get in some other restaurants. And the sushi-man is Japanese. Stop by and say hi to Eiichi-san. Really nice guy.

reviews.name: E Thomas B.
reviews.review: Food was alright. Barely recognizable as sushi. While not busy waitress barely attended to us. Asked for beer to be brought out with dinner so it would remain  cold but instead it was brought out immediately left to get warm while we waited for our food while sitting outside.

reviews.name: Rachel M.
reviews.review: This is (so far) my favorite sushi spot in Nashville. I love, love, LOVE the Gabe roll. It is literally one of the best things I have ever tasted. I know, I know, it's not West Coast sushi, but for Tennessee? Pretty damn good. I also love the Marilyn Monroe. I was a little wary after reading the description of it (jalapeno in sushi?), but it is wonderful. I suggest trying it. I suggest trying their version of the Fireball roll as well. You know what? I suggest everything on the menu. I haven't had it all yet, but it's bound to be good. Bonus? Super-friendly service. I ate there by myself today (husband and I were going two separate places), and my server did not try to make me feel weird about eating alone. I've had that happen to me at other places. I am so sad that I live nowhere near this little restaurant anymore.

reviews.name: Andy R.
reviews.review: I had another great meal at Sushi O Sushi!  I love this place.  The owners are very nice, and the sushi is excellent. They are a bit pricey, but the food is well worth the price.  I always get the sushi when I am there, so I really cannot comment on the other dishes.  They have a very good selection of rolls, and they all look delicious.  The menu has photos and descriptions of the rolls, so choosing is made easy.  My favorite is the Fuji Mountain roll........yummy!!  If you are in the area, be sure and give Sushi O Sushi a try.

reviews.name: Scott M.
reviews.review: Sushi is great, service is mediocre at best. Love the 25% off rolls on Wednesday special, though.

reviews.name: Meredith H.
reviews.review: I love sushi, and this place makes me love it even more! In and out for $7 including tip! Service was good. I'm still giving it 5 stars even though we weren't greeted when we walked in and we weren't sure if we were supposed to seat ourselves, but the waitress was so nice. There's a sushi place right across the street (Sushi Me, I think), but  Sushi O Sushi has way better hours and they're very affordable. Delicious!

reviews.name: Sara C.
reviews.review: The boy and I took a weekend trip to Nashville, and decided to stop by this place since one of our old friends works here.  The restaurant is at the end of a strip mall, and is pleasantly but not remarkably decorated inside.  The menu is a bit overwhelming at first, especially the three pages full of pictures in the back, but our friend walked us through the different choices and made comments about his favourites.  We ended up staying pretty basic with a rainbow roll, a lucky roll, and salmon nigiri.  It was well prepared and hit the spot after a long day of driving.  It was a little pricy - forty something dollars after tip - but enjoyable.

reviews.name: Rachel F.
reviews.review: The egg rolls are fantastic, the sushi is unique and delicious with great presentation and the staff is very thoughtful.  First time here and I will be back often.

reviews.name: Jaycee L.
reviews.review: I was seriously disappointed. I was so excited to have a walking distance sushi place-- but this place was not up to par for sushi. Maybe I came on a bad night-- I had the spicy tuna roll-- nothing was spicy about it. The rolls kept falling apart as I tried to dip into the soy sauce. My fiance and I love sushi but will not be coming back here. The prices are cheap, but... I feel that I did get what I paid for :(

reviews.name: Barry M.
reviews.review: Have been here twice and the quality is consistent. The sushi is very good . The menu is a bit difficult to wade through but otherwise this is a very good choice for sushi

reviews.name: Kenneth B.
reviews.review: This is a terrific addition and compliment to the Lenox Village area retail choices.  We were in the mood for sushi but didn't want to drive to far so we found this place on our yelp app.  We weren't expecting to have a "Wow" but were very impressed by the food, customer service and location.  We had the No 9, Spicy Tuna Roll, Kim's Roll, Dragon Roll, and potstickers.  We enjoyed all the rolls and the fresh ingredients stood out.  The potstickers were overcooked but good flavor.  My favorite was the simplest, the Spicy Tuna Roll, the quality and portion of the tuna served were excellent.  For those that live on the Davidson County-Williamson County line in the Lenox Village area - this is definitely worth a try!

reviews.name: Bret D.
reviews.review: Good sushi and reasonable prices.  They offer a multitude (so many it is hard to make a choice) of interesting rolls and the service is pleasant and efficient.  It is a bit on the small side so you may have a wait on weekend nights.  It is not as hip as the place across the street, Sushi Me, but it is a better value.  Decor is your typical traditional Japanese restaurant theme with a few buddhas, some silk screens, etc.

reviews.name: Travis A.
reviews.review: Mmmmmm... spicy scallop hand rolls.  NOM NOM NOMI just finished a nice round of take out from Sushi O Sushi.  This being the first night of Snowpocalypse 2011, I decided to brave the empty streets of Nashvegas and slide on down to the local sushi spot.  I figured they didn't carry any gallons of milk or loaves of bread, so I should be safe from the crazy hoarders.  Surprisingly, there were about 5 tables occupied.I've eaten here about 7 or 8 times and have never had a bad meal.  I like places that get original with rolls and mix it up a little.  They do some amazing things with fresh fruit and fish here.  The Double Double roll is AMAZING.  The Spicy Tempura roll was excellent.  Their prices are on the slightly above average side for Nashville, but their variety, quality and freshness make up for it.  Their specialized rolls take up about 3 pages in the back of the menu and each has a decent picture/description to accompany it.  With this, you get a good idea of how it is prepared, which always helps when trying something new.  Unfortunately, this also gives you soo much to choose from which can be tough to narrow down.On a side note, I did get annoyed at the Droid Yelp app because it told me I was too far to check in, although I was sitting at the sushi bar.Overall, this is a good sushi spot in South Nashville.  Yes, the sushi menu is big, but their food is good enough to keep coming back to try all of the rolls.

reviews.name: Leslie J.
reviews.review: I don't understand why people like this place. The menu is heavy with fried rolls rather than fresh fish. The sashimi is tiny, and it's all over-priced. With Sushime across the street, I don't know how this place can stay in business.

reviews.name: Lashona M.
reviews.review: Great customer service, atmosphere and not overcrowded! I liked the japanese pop music! As for the price, no more expensive than any other establishment. Pretty good sushi and fresh too! I had the fried shrimp roll, dragon roll, and Harumaki Japanese Spring Roll. Those spring rolls were unique and had a strange texture but oddly good. I'd go back.

reviews.name: Brettaney V.
reviews.review: The worst I've ever had. Miso soup is hot toilet water- gross. Sushi is so-so-/ not horrible- not good. I should have just gone that extra mile down the road 2 THE BEST SUSHI n town! Sushi Me

reviews.name: Candice R.
reviews.review: I went in for a late lunch. I had the spicy scallop roll, yellowtail, and the happy roll. The spicy scallop was all hot sauce so I was disappointed. the yellowtail and scallion is my old standby at any sushi joint and my fish was poorly prepped, there was some connective tissue on my roll. The happy roll was okay but it was hard to find a special roll without any cream cheese or fried shrimp and that was one of few.

reviews.name: Sean R.
reviews.review: This is by far the best sushi place in and around Nashville. The atmosphere is always amazing and never too crowded. The meal comes quickly and I've yet to have a bad piece of sushi yet in almost 4 years of going back! I love the staff and their service. It always seems like they are thankful for your business and appreciate you as a customer. The Nashville roll is by far the best in town!

reviews.name: James R.
reviews.review: It's kinda hard to review this place.  I mean, sure, it's a bit on the pricey side.  Granted.  But not horribly so.  And you know what?  It may be pricey, but really - you do get what you pay for.I mean, c'mon - STRAWBERRY & KIWI sushi?!  ZOMG.  Seriously, it was weird and funky and absolutely dee-freaking-licious.  I will admit now.  I was a bad Yelper.  I don't remember at all the names of the sushi rolls that wifey and I threw down.  I remember fruit.  And avocado.  And fried awesomeness.  Yeah, we spent $50 on like four rolls.  Worth every penny.P.S. DON'T, I repeat, DON'T waste your money on the tempura app platter.  Not great, and super small.  The only blemish on the beauty of the sushi artwork.

reviews.name: Sadie F.
reviews.review: The sushi here is pretty good! I've been here a few times various nights of the weeks and have experienced prompt and friendly service, and for a small place I'm glad there has not yet been a wait for a table. Although it is not the best I've ever had, the sushi is pretty fresh tasting. It will satisfy your sushi fix for sure! Once you get past the overwhelming amount of options of specialty rolls, you will find average sushi prices and average tasting dishes. Usually we start out with the house salad & ginger dressing, which is pretty tasty. I've tried the rainbow roll, spicy tuna, philly roll and others that had really crazy names- i think fuji was one that I tried, overall consensus is to stay away from eel at this place. My boyfriend had a roll that was very sweet with fruit on it- it was so so good.

reviews.name: Max S.
reviews.review: I dont know what to say about this place, other than the fish tasted really fresh and clean?...if that makes any sense. The service was a delight, the decor, a little superficial, maybe institutionalized. There are a lot of choices on the menu which is a plus, the dynamite roll is just that...Dynamite!!

reviews.name: Melanie B.
reviews.review: The more I go there the more I like it. The prices can be steep on some of the rolls, but are about the same as other places. I love the james bond roll with jalapenos. They have some different things that I haven't seen at other places. it is usually not busy and is pretty small. So, a great place to go if you are ready to eat right away. they won 2nd place for best sushi in nashville, so that should tell you something about the quality! I actually like it better than Peter's sushi.

reviews.name: Michael L.
reviews.review: Best sushi ever!  Love the James Bond, Marilyn Monroe and Fireball!

reviews.name: doug d.
reviews.review: Love this place.While I have only been twice so far, I really like the place.Pros: Quite, nice atmosphere inside and out. Sushi rice is actually done very well... unfortunately that seems rare around here as in most places the rice is mush.Udon soups are some of the best I have had.Nice friendly waitress.Cons: Kinda far away for most people I would think, and a little pricey.

reviews.name: Casey P.
reviews.review: *Disclaimer: I am incredibly picky when it comes to sushi. I think when you've lived in Boston and NYC, you're allowed to be. What can I say? I'm a snob.*Simply put, this place rocks. I went in for the first time tonight after finally figuring out that there's a sushi place not even 3 miles down the road from my house. I sat at the bar, and the sushi chef was as delightful as they come. Super friendly, helpful, and entertaining. I ordered some sashimi and a spicy tuna roll, and everything was delicious. The salmon was super fresh and had that perfect melts-in-your-mouth buttery taste, the tuna was perfect, yellowtail was delightful.Everyone was very friendly, attentive, and overall this was one of my favorite dinner experiences thus far in Nashvegas. The place was clean, and yes, it's a bit more expensive than some other local places, but well worth the price. Overall, I think I've found my new sushi joint.

reviews.name: John G.
reviews.review: I have nothing against my dinner here, I just think it was nothing special.  I think the sushi was not as good as Peters, and the atmosphere was not as good as Sushiyobi (or Sam's), and the price was on the high side. The space was nice, but I don't see myself making big plans to go back.

reviews.name: Carrie S.
reviews.review: Horrible service, bad music and better sushi across the street.  My husband and I went here and he does not eat cream cheese.  We specifically ordered all rolls without cream cheese.  The server brought it out and it had cream cheese.  We nicely asked that we have another without the cream cheese.  Not our mistake I was very specific.  Then a lady ( think one of the owners came over) very rudely told us that we would still have to pay for it and then the scolded the server.  I cannot believe she expected us to pay for it!  We gladly go across the street. Much better vibe, service and most of all sushi!

reviews.name: Robert K.
reviews.review: I have no qualms about the food at Sushi O Sushi, except that it is a bit too pricy for what you get.  Aside from that, my meal was quite good.  I had the Hawaiian which included shrimp, asparagus, cream cheese, MANGO, and avocado!  The mango was a really nice touch, as I found that the sweetness balanced out the saltiness of the cream cheese very well.  The presentation was excellent and was laid out on a long narrow plate with sauce drizzled on top, very pleasing to the eye.  Sushi O Sushi has a large selection of Asian style of beers to choose from, far more than I have seen in any other Asian style restaurant.  I give it three stars instead of four because it is just too over priced.  *great happy hour specials*

reviews.name: Stefanie P.
reviews.review: Yes, its in a strip-mall next to a 24 hour gym. It is small. The service isn't very personable. They have a great menu with description and photos. Rolls are huge. Huge pieces. Drink menu was weak a few selections. I like their variety, and the taste is good, but average priced and you're not getting anything but some good sushi. Kinda a drive from downtown nashville, make sure you google how far it is from where you're at.

reviews.name: Mitch S.
reviews.review: pricey ,not a good bang for the buck  food is so so ,scallops are the size of #2 pencil erasers they are open til 10 pm for the late crowdservice is fine glad it's here but it's not on my don't miss list.hanabi or peters is one level up and then some

reviews.name: kristen p.
reviews.review: I keep driving by this place on my way to visit best friend out in Nolensville. We are both avid fans of Peter's Sushi in Brentwood but finally caved in and decided to try it. (the name is just so cute!)The place itself is small but nicely decorated and feels very clean. Our waitress was very attentive. I ended up ordering 2 rolls. (As a rule I refuse to eat anything raw on a first visit to any sushi bar. ) So I had the crunchy shrimp roll and one of their specials the gabe roll. Both were good and tasted very fresh. The worst part of the evening was getting the check. Two rolls, some miso soup, and a cup of green tea later I owed $17.70. Seemed a little pricey for me. Especially for Nolensville. But over all this place is good.

reviews.name: Mr Mrs J.
reviews.review: I have driven by this place a gazillion times, and I finally broke down and tried it last week.  I was not disappointed, in fact, I liked it.  After eating sushi for almost 9 years now, and tasting some of the best sushi in the country, not bad for a neighborhood sushi joint.  The sushi was fresh and service was good.  I'll come back again.  Good place for lunch I would say.   Before I give 4 stars to a restaurant, I would have to try it at dinner time as well.  Sometimes lunch and dinner can be a big difference.  I would recommend it for lunch though.

reviews.name: Rahel K.
reviews.review: Leigh & John are right on with this place.  Expensive for what you get.  The rolls are the size you get at grocery stores.  Very small!  But the service is very good, and atmosphere is ok (good lighting, decor).   Peter's is much better.  If you don't want to drive all the way to Brentwood for sushi, I would choose Minami down the street.

reviews.name: Randal L.
reviews.review: I have patronized International Market nearly 40 years. While finishing my degree at Belmont late 80s and 90s, later while living close by in early 2000s I was there once or more per week. It is great for what it is: low cost steam -tray-held Thai food. Best bet for freshness is to order soup- noodle soup with vegetables, or lemongrass or chicken soup with rice for example. I personally like the Eggplant Curry or Tofu Curry when it is wayyyy over cooked. The chicken on a stick is not recommended. Fried foods at front of line are best when fresh which is rare. Pad wun sen not recommended for Thai purists; despite all these criticisms the Market has charm, affordability, and usually neat clientele. Closed Sundays. Four stars for economy and charm. Food is a three at best but I keep returning.

reviews.name: Ashley T.
reviews.review: Wow some of these reviews are spot on.I called in an order of pad Thai with tofu and no egg around 3:30 on a Friday. When I arrived less than 10 mins later, it was ready to go. I also grabbed a vegetarian curry egg roll and a sweet rice cake from the buffet. My total was $11.75, which I thought was a really good deal for as much food as I got. There were all kinds of maneki nekko kitties and bobble heads that I wanted to check out but I was starving. I drove home and ate. First of all, the sweet rice cake. The flavor was fine. It reminded me of the rice cakes my friend's Filipino mother made for us growing up. Some of the rice was undercooked though so it was hard around the edges. The veg curry egg roll was different. Not as much curry flavor I expected which was kind of a bummer. The dipping sauce was almost honey-like in flavor but had a really watery consistency. Not like any Thai dipping sauce I've tried before. Not my favorite. And lastly, the pad Thai. This is where the other reviews come into play. The first couple bites seemed like your average Americanized pad Thai dish. It was alright. But some bites throughout tasted almost spoiled. The mung bean sprouts looked more like DUNG bean sprouts. (Budump chhhh! I'll be here all night, folks. On the couch, with an upset stomach) They were really dark (some black) and wilted, whereas fresh sprouts are white/green in color and crisp. There were maybe 6 total pieces of tofu and I truly couldn't tell if they were what tasted off or if it was the bean sprouts or a mix of everything. I gave this place 2 stars because the guy behind the buffet was really nice and so was the lady who rang me up, but I won't be eating here again.

reviews.name: Kelly Ann W.
reviews.review: Never going back there again. Everything was mushy and old. Smelled weird/ spoiled. Just spent $15 to dump it in the trash. Totally gross. Store is interesting full of fun things.

reviews.name: Simon T.
reviews.review: Yikes. Started tasty,but there is NO FREAKING WAYthat stuff is fresh. NOPE.

reviews.name: Steven W.
reviews.review: This place has been here since 1975. Belmont University has built up around it now. They have the same food on the buffet they did back then. It's full of funkiness and it's pretty clean.Chicken stick, sweet sticky rice cake. Yum

reviews.name: SueAnn S.
reviews.review: The food is passable, correction. The food from the made to order menu is passable. The food on the buffet is disgusting. I never order from the buffet because I don't trust that the food hasn't been sitting there for hours. Order from the back, they have a made to order menu. I usually get the pho. It's not the best in town but it's a decent price for a lunch in this part of town if you want Asian.

reviews.name: Ed P.
reviews.review: Great little out of the way place. From the outside it pretty much looks like a dive restaurant.  Inside the smell of Thai and Asian cooking will draw you in.   Everything on the steam table looked fresh when I got there.  I had placed a carry out order which they had ready.  They took extra to pack the soup in a box so it wouldn't spill.   They placed the noodle for the soup in a separate container so they wouldn't got soggy.  The chicken noodle soup was wonderful and had a garlic edge to it.   The pork buns were just like my favorite ones I used to get when I worked it Shanghai.   They won major points for this.  I will be going back to try other selections off of the menu for sure.

reviews.name: Danielle D.
reviews.review: Great place for Thai that is authentic snd inexpensive. Hole in the wall atmosphere and it's very popular with the locals.

reviews.name: Neely M.
reviews.review: This is one of those places you hope never change. I have been eating here since 1990. I don't live in Nashville any more but when I am home I try to stop in. It feels so natural to sit and have a delicious egg rolls, chicken on a stick, or fried rice.

reviews.name: Led D.
reviews.review: The place is cafeteria style. Mostly everything are pre-cooked so all you have to do is point and it will be served to your plate.You can also order from the menu. So I ordered a duck noodle soup and my son ordered the beef noodle. The rest of the family ordered off the pre-cooked entree.Both soups were great. As matter of fact the last time I had that type of broth was when we were in Thai Town Los Angeles, Calfornia. It was very good and quite satisfying.As for the rest of the food it was okay or maybe great for people that has not been to Thailand. The flavor is decent but need to be more spicier.This place is also right around the corner of Belmont University, so prices were very affordable.Great place for lunch plate and cheap eats.

reviews.name: Charles L.
reviews.review: Quite possibly the worst restaurant I have tried in years.  I decided to give this place a try around 6:00PM and at 11:00PM my stomach is still upset.  I tried the fried rice and chicken curry from the buffet.  It seemed sketchy but that does not always mean the food is bad.  In this case, it did.  As soon as I got my plate, I noticed that something smelled rotten but I thought it could not possibly be the food I just ordered.  I went to the cash register, paid, and sat down to eat.  The first bite sickened me.  The chicken was dry/rubbery and tasted fishy/rotten.  I took another bite just to make sure I was not hallucinating.  I had to throw everything away and leave.  At least it was cheap.  My stomach has been turning ever since.  Hopefully I have not been food poisoned.  I would not recommend this restaurant to my worst enemy.

reviews.name: N T.
reviews.review: I wouldn't call the food good, but it's cheap. The only item on the menu that's noteworthy is the curry egg roll, which is quite decent. I feel like you're probably better off sticking to the non-meat options, but the tofu curry is pretty bland; I'd go with the eggplant or noodle curries.And I'm always a sucker for Thai iced tea, which you can get if you hand them a cup with some ice in it. The people working there are very nice and will make motherly comments if they feel you aren't getting enough food.

reviews.name: Bj C.
reviews.review: I hate to describe this place as kind of a hole in the wall but that's the best way I can think of to describe it. It's not like a chain restaurant with bright lights and a commercial atmosphere. It's so casual you feel like you're sitting in someone's house having some amazing food! I had never had Thai food before and this was a great first impression. My boyfriend lived in Nashville for years and was quite excited to bring me here. There was some type of banana pudding wrapped in a leaf and the ladies behind the counter kept saying to not eat the leaf. Ha! Apparently a lot of customers don't think to unwrap it first. :) I look forward to going back. A great place!

reviews.name: Cy W.
reviews.review: Absolutely disgusting. Only tried two vegetarian dishes in the buffet (perhaps the al a carte is more reliable?): the spring roll was like rubber filled with ground hoof, and the broccoli with rice noodles was in edible - it tasted like it had been in the back corner of a meat locker for months on end. No exaggeration.

reviews.name: Virginia S.
reviews.review: I wanted to like this place. It's right down the  street from my house and I'm often walking to bongo java and blvd. I love noodle soups, udon and pho and have eaten it all over town. The chicken pho here is bland and unappealing. The chicken has zero taste and is a bit chewy. The chicken fried rice was just not good. I am not a picky eater and am not bothered at all by a hole in the wall type of setting, I actually prefer it but I won't be back here to eat. If you want good noodle soup go to Thai Esane or Kien Giang.

reviews.name: R B.
reviews.review: The ladies here are amazing.The buffet style food, I think, is a little sketchy...my stomach did not like it...but it may be different for you!  It's definitely a place you should give a try.I love their tom-yum soup...and their kimchee is really fresh to buy for home.

reviews.name: Miranda M.
reviews.review: Been going here since I was little, best pepper steak and fried rice you can get. The egg rolls and the sauce you get with them is great. It's a hole in the wall and I wouldn't consider eating there from the looks of it had my family not already been going here for years. Don't let the looks deceive you, it's great food. Also a lot of food for your money.

reviews.name: Courtney P.
reviews.review: I had the Pad Thai off the menu, asked for it spicy. It was not at all spicy and sickly sweet. It was really disappointing

reviews.name: Jasmine K.
reviews.review: It was okay.. Just Cheap Thai Food. The Market itself had a great variety of stuff.. but definitely marked up. I would suggest the Curry Chicken roll.. That was really good.

reviews.name: Eli G.
reviews.review: This place is very much a hit or miss. Please do not go at an unusual time. Stick to typical meal times. When they are on their game it is fantastic. When they aren't...not so much. Back when it first opened it was almost entirely an Asian grocery store hence the market part that throws some people off. I would definitely recommend this place if you're looking for something quick and easy. Again, go at a typical meal time.

reviews.name: Ja R.
reviews.review: Great Thai food at the best price.Tom Yum soup is the best.Good for take out or a quick stop and eat.We like to try different restaurants but this is one place that we have been back more than a couple of times.

reviews.name: Ali B.
reviews.review: Where else do you find curry paste, coconut milk, and Asian fruit gummies? This place is a landmine for odd cooking ingredients and quick Thai food. If not to check out the random sake sets, chopsticks, and Asian novelties, come for the super friendly service. I was referred to as 'lady' and 'honey' at least five times while checking out. Nothing like friendly service to put a smile on my face at the end of a long day :)

reviews.name: Kh T.
reviews.review: Let me start by saying I've lived in Asia for many years, so I'm not afraid to eat off a styrofoam plate. In fact, some of the best food you can eat comes that way. That being said, The International Market & Restaurant is absolutely the worst dining experience I have ever had. Where to begin? You can go through the buffet where the server will try to upsell you on a variety of dodgey looking dishes. Or you can take a menu and order from the kitchen through the cashier. We chose the buffet and ordered fried rice, spicy pork, siam chicken, pork bun and chive dumpling. The fried rice was the worst I ever had, both meat dishes were over cooked and sweeted to the point of nausea.The pork bun, I had to spit out. The chive dumpling was a soggy mess. I honestly don't know how this place can stay in business. Please, do not go here, ever! You might be tempted by seeminly economical buffet set up, but you'll end up paying just as much as any other place. I'm getting a little sick just thinking about it. UGH!

reviews.name: Gia N.
reviews.review: great food for cheap prices..the owner is kinda stingy with plastic utensils

reviews.name: Stacy T.
reviews.review: I'd echo what some others have said and admit that the place is a tad expensive. Especially if you order from the menu and not the buffet, you'll pay a little more. However, the red curry from the menu is some of the best in Nashville. It's so delicious and maybe $10. If you order from the buffet, it is sometimes hit-or-miss, so I generally order from the menu. This is a great place for a quick Thai lunch since you can get your food, eat, and be gone rather quickly.

reviews.name: Charles C.
reviews.review: It's best to order off of the menu instead of eating what's on the buffet line.  I really love the chicken noodle, lemongrass, and tom kha soups!  I also like the different dumplings they offer.

reviews.name: Dana T.
reviews.review: My go to for carry out....Pad thai from the kitchen! Staff is always friendly!

reviews.name: Wayne H.
reviews.review: Small world market with limited ethnic food and supplies and fairly high prices.  The buffet items looked and smelled terrible, a mixture of Americanized Asian cuisine and staleness that comes from being under a heat lamp too long.  The only reason for the continued survival of this place is likely due to its proximity to Belmont. Skip and visit the ethnic markets and restaurants along Charlotte Pike instead.

reviews.name: Laurie S.
reviews.review: I don't make it over to the Belmont area too much anymore since I stopped working over there.  However, when I did I frequented this lovely place.  The atmosphere is interesting.  It's a mix of a hole-in-the-wall restaurant that you might wonder about the quality of food and grocery with lots of fun stuff to look through (and purchase if you like to use Asian spices and ingredients).  To me, this place is all about the food though.I have only ever had the buffet.  If you go at lunch it will be fresh however the later in the day you go, the more it sits.  It's not as good then.  So go at lunch.  I always start with the vegetable curry spring roll, they are so wonderfully crispy I could make a meal out of them.  If I did that though I would miss out on my favorite dish:  the Spicy Chicken Stick.  Yep.  It's chicken on a stick.  And I have to say that when you look at it sitting there in the sauce (which has a delectable coconut flavor to it) it doesn't look very appetizing.  But it is.  So.  Very.  Good.  Get some fried or steamed rice and a stick of chicken.  It's not spicy hot so you could doctor it but get one!Thank you, International Market, for the wonderful food.  I will be back again soon.

reviews.name: Joanna F.
reviews.review: I was a Belmont student, so I came here when my other friends wanted to eat here. I'd come here alone if I was really craving (subpar) asian food. Hey, it's literally a one minute walk to get there from Belmont.So this place is a little market (packaged good, grocery, cooking utensils, and trinkets) and a restaurant. The food menu consists of a buffet line and a special menu. If I want cheap, greasy food, I go for the buffet line. I think I've had almost everything they've had to offer in the buffet. I usually end up topping it off with chilli sauce and Sriracha so it's spicy and has more flavor. The items on the Special Menu are made in the kitchen in the back. They cost about $8. They're ok, nothing to rave on and on about. Oh, and if ordering from the back, you can tell them if you want more or less or none of an ingredient. My friend loves fried garlic, so she always ask for that and to make it as spicy as possible. They are more than happy to attend to her request. I've been there enough to know that this place has regulars, and they seem pretty hardcore about it too. Pros: Quick, Near Belmont, have tofu and vegetable option instead of chicken and beef.Cons: Mediocre food, staff can seem distant and a little rude.

reviews.name: Ruiqiu K.
reviews.review: I finally came back to try the buffet. Sadly, I will have to give it a pass.First off, the food did not look appetizing. And this coming from someone like me who has spent 20 years being a loyal customer to various buffet-type places with heat lamps galore.My go-to Thai order is pad thai. And this version was exceedingly bland. I always like it when there are green onions in my pad thai; there were none in this version. No tofu, but there is scrambled egg -- even for the vegetarian version. Admittedly, I asked for it mild. But I somehow sense that had I ordered it spicy, the only difference would be the addition of chiles, rather than more sauce. Rather than throw the rest of the order away, I saved it for home, where I made my own pad thai sauce. I had thankfully brought over a few bricks of tamarind paste during my move from the West Coast. I neglected to buy Thai fish sauce here -- so I had to make my version with soy sauce rather than fish sauce. Regardless, I ended up with a pad thai with flavor -- too bad I had to add the flavor myself.I also had the chicken with some sweet sauce. This I could not enjoy at all. I like sweet sauces with my meat dishes. But when the consistency of the sauce reminds me of snot...well, I'm sorry, even I have boundaries. I like using corn starch when I make these types of sweet sauces, and I don't think it does that.  But I don't know what Thais use or what this restaurant uses to make it look like that.I did peruse a bit more at their little market. Bought some Chinese rice crackers that did remind me a little bit of my easier accessibility to these goods back home.I pass this place daily by bus...I will have to take a permanent pass on stepping inside.

reviews.name: Em S.
reviews.review: For Nashville, this place has pretty decent Southeast Asian food for the price. (Of course, in a larger city, this place probably would be taken out by the competition... and this place is by no means trying to compete with even moderately upscale restaurants - for that, go to PM across the street which is owned by the same family) There is a cafeteria-style buffet with a fairly large selection, which is fresh for lunch but gets a little stale by the end of the dinner... $2 will get you a fairly large scoop of a dish such as spicy eggplant or tofu curry or vegetable fried rice. So for $4-6, you can really fill up! Quite affordable, and almost unbeatable in price for a quick meal. They also have many "fresh-cut" fruit and dessert options as well as various canned drinks like coconut juice and soy milk, as well as lots of Asian imported candies. Now, if the buffet food looks like it's been sitting out too long, you can order off the menu too... the menu is hard to find and isn't very much beyond your typical Pad Thai, noodle-soup , or curry dishes with your choice of protein, but at least it's made fresh to order. You order at the cash register, and they will bring it out to your table (or package it for carry-out). The dishes are almost all $8, and come out very quickly in decent portion size. The decor is, well, interesting. Half the store is taken up by Asian imported groceries and sundries - great for a quick purchase of a spice or sauce or lucky bamboo. If you're expecting formal or romantic dining, then this is not the place. Don't come here for an anniversary dinner! There is no waiter service, no tablecloths, just hard booths and old tables, so it's faster and cheaper that way. And eating in a variety store next to elephant statues and Thai art for sale - it makes for a more unique dining experience for many!

reviews.name: Simon K.
reviews.review: So when it comes to the high rating, this place is skewed b/c of the college students that review the place.  In college, I would've wrote a 4 star review for "easy mac."  Plus if you're going to Belmont or Vandy, you're dishing out about $40k a year for tuition and asking for Figi water at restaurants, then forgive me if I'm skeptical about your sense of value of a dollar.  An entree here may be under $10, but that doesn't make it cheap.  The quality is horrible... I take that back.  I can't tell if the quality is horrible.  When you have food sitting out for hours, it hard to tell what it started out as.  So if they do use good ingredients, you definitely can't tell by the time it gets to your plate.  And if you stop by any other Asian market in town, you know they're marking up their prices way up there.  Food left out like that isn't safe, and the food that you order from the menu still comes out over cooked.  And if you're taking advantage of the college students there, then at least put some money back into the restaurant to update the equipment, furniture and decor.  College student may not have taste buds yet, but their eyes work just fine.  At least make it look like it's worth the money you're charging.

reviews.name: Rachel S.
reviews.review: I can't explain why it's taken me so many years to finally eat at and shop around this little restaurant with a built-in grocery.  Or is it a grocery with a built-in restaurant?  Seating for the restaurant takes up the entire space, with shelves of Asian goods tucked in the only available corners.  Need obscure Asian groceries?  You'll find them here.I glanced over the really large cafeteria-style layout of inexpensively priced items and thought - this isn't really Thai food.  Most of these dishes are halfway Chinese, with a few coconut curries and and some thin rice noodles.  There was a sign for Thai Tea available, and a nice assortment of fresh cut fruits in plastic tubs to finish off one's meal.  I was confused.  I thought I was in for some killer Thai cuisine.  I was also hungrier than I've felt in a really, REALLY long time.  So when asked "For here or to go?" I replied "For here" and began to make choices off of the "buffet".  I chose the rice noodles in chili sauce, the vegetable curry, and some veggie dumplings.  Uhhh.. it was all okay, for Chinese cafeteria-style food that has been sitting in a heated tin for hours upon hours.  The two wet dishes were quite oily.  I sort of felt like I could have made them both at home.  The dumplings, like everything offered in the restaurant, were homemade, and I wonder if they contained TVP.  Not a problem, just an observations.Of course, as I finished my meal, I realized there is a SEPARATE Thai menu of items which are cooked to order.  How could I have known??  There was an 8 1/2x11 inch piece of laminated paper hanging on the right wall, as the start of the "buffet", that listed all of the available Thai items.  If you've never been here before, know this before you go!  While the cafeteria options were fine for a quick and inexpensive meal, I have a feeling the Thai meals this restaurant offers will go WAY above and beyond what I ate today.The price at the International Restaurant is RIGHT.  It is pleasingly inexpensive, and the portions are very large.  You will not leave hungry, even if you accidentally order something less than stellar.

reviews.name: Cheryl B.
reviews.review: This is just for the little market. This has a neat little selection of mostly Thai foods, spices and condiments. In a pinch, it's OK. Everything is well stocked and there's enough variety of other Asian items if you need it.

reviews.name: Will M.
reviews.review: I love Pho.  Their version has Beef broth that is rich.  More chinese style, they like to toss garlic on top of the noodle soup.  I liked it but warning, varies from your traditional vietnamese chain pho.  This place has been a mainstay circa 1975, they offer dimsum items and other buffet type items for quick eats.  If you're smart, order from their kitchen.  Fresh food is always better than food that's been sitting there longer than 20 minutes.  Very outgoing cashier, lovely lady named Patti.  Almost tempted me into some dim sum, which looked decent, but it was sitting there and I don't do buffet style food.

reviews.name: Bob B.
reviews.review: I was not happy at all. I had the Chicken Satay and the Crab ragoon. The Ragoon was cold, and the peanut sauce with the chicken was horrible. I actually felt sick after eatting here today. If you want good Satay go to Satay's. The place is kinda dirty, I expected more from all the good reviews, but these people must not have ate good thai before. They need to up their game a bit.

reviews.name: Robin S.
reviews.review: This is a good lunch place if you're in a hurry or want to grab take-out.  It's buffet style, which can be good and bad...good because it's quick and easy and you can see everything up front; bad because you can see everything up front (some looked as though it had been sitting out a while).  Needless to say, food is decent--I stuck with the Thai choices (spicy coconut chicken skewers and egg noodles with veggies) and would eat it again for sure.  They also have various Chinese dishes...didn't look as appetizing.  In addition to the hot food ready to serve, there is a large non-fancy dining room, as well as "grocery" section containing a large selection of international foods, spices, sauces, etc.  Again--not my favorite place to grab Thai food, but I'll go back if I'm in a hurry.

reviews.name: Todd S.
reviews.review: Popped in for a late lunch with good friend who had never been before. We had immediate service, tons of fresh options, and very friendly staff. It was an easy in and out dining experience. If it was closer to my home office, I would carry out lunch frequently! Thanks!

reviews.name: Lulu S.
reviews.review: This place gets 2 stars because I'm still alive. Imagine a picture of your usual Americanized Asian food. Now apply a sepia effect to that picture, and you get the food on the buffet line here. The pineapple chicken tasted like rubber, and the red bean bun was so dry, my friend used a spoon to scoop out the filling and discarded the rest. The only saving grace was the fried rice.I did not notice that we could order off the menu, and when I asked the owner, he just pointed to the hot plates and gave no indication that there's a kitchen in the back. Perhaps the freshly prepared dishes are more appetizing, but this Asian girl shall (happily) never find out.

reviews.name: Chad R.
reviews.review: This is a very cool place to visit fun lunch.  Part grocery store for Asian food and part restaurant.  I have never purchased any of the groceries there but I like to look at all the interesting merchandise they have on the shelves.  I always go there for lunch though.  The food is very good and I really like to add their hot sauce to the food to spice things up.  The staff is always extremely friendly and very nice.  This is a great place for lunch but it does not have the type of atmosphere that you would like to go with friends or a date for dinner.  I will continue to make this a destination for lunch when I want fast Thai food.

reviews.name: Anna M.
reviews.review: I love this place so much. Don't be intimidated by the weird set up or the workers. I've talked all of my friends into going with me at least once and they have all loved it! My staple meal is fried rice with sesame chicken from the buffet line. They also always have freshly sliced fruit in the fridge at the en of the buffet. Fresh sliced mango? Yes please. An entire meal under 5 dollars? Double yes please. Their chicken pad thai is also incredible, so delicious. Going to Belmont makes it an obvious choice for a quick meal because it's basically on campus, but if you're looking for cheap, good thai food, go here. It's totally worth it.

reviews.name: Yonnie B.
reviews.review: Located inside an Asian grocery store.The extensive asian buffet is cheap.  But some of the items look like they've been sitting there for a day too many. We ordered off the menu.We got a sloppy looking and tasting pad thai.  The noodles were cooked way too long.  They went too heavy on the sweet sauce.  Skimpy on the vegetables, hard on the chilli.  Underwhelming.  I hate sloppy cooking.The larb pork was better.  Lots of lime juice, garlic, fresh onion, cilantro and chilli.  The big disappointment was that there was as much pork fat as there was pork meat.  It tasted great but I had to pick all the bits of fat out of the dish.  I finished with a mound of pig fat on my plate. They are one of the few establishments that charge for water.  I think this is a crime.  Up the prices if you need to but DON'T CHARGE FOR WATER! It's cheap and nasty.But the women are so smiley and friendly.. the atmosphere so chilled.. it breaks my iron heart to have to be so harsh.  This is a place that's probably perfect for a poor student that's out to get full quickly and not feeling like fried chicken or a burger and fries.  If you're after a good Thai food experience, I say steer clear.

reviews.name: Wes K.
